cheatsheetvideos.quote: Karla only needed to Study for 1 hour. She then went to the DMV and Passed her test
DMV Test Cheat Sheet: John Tells us How to Ace The Driver’s Test On your First Try

questions.question: You come to an intersection that is blocked by other traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Go slowly until the traffic ahead moves.
questions.answerB: Get as close as possible to the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Stay out of the intersection until you can pass through.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn to make the cars move up.
questions.explanation: You cannot enter an intersection if traffic is backed up on the other side and you cannot get completely through the intersection. Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection.

questions.question: A driver entering interstate traffic from an entrance or acceleration ramp:
questions.answerA: Should yield to drivers already on the interstate.
questions.answerB: Has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: May force their way into traffic.
questions.answerD: Can assume that other drivers will change lanes to make room.
questions.explanation: If you are on an entrance or acceleration ramp and are entering interstate traffic, you should yield to drivers already on the interstate highway. Merge safely into traffic when you are able to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Work crew ahead.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that there is an upcoming sharp turn and that they should lower their speed accordingly.

questions.question: A flashing red traffic signal at an intersection has the same requirements as:
questions.answerB: A yield sign.
questions.answerC: A stop sign.
questions.explanation: When approaching a flashing red signal, you must stop and yield to all traffic that does not have to stop.

questions.question: When driving under icy or snowy conditions, which driving technique will help drivers avoid crashes?
questions.answerA: Add extra weight to their vehicles to improve traction.
questions.answerB: Get off the highways as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Engage the four-wheel drive on their vehicles.
questions.answerD: Reduce their speed and increase their following distance.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when roads are snow-covered or icy. Doing this and increasing your following distance are the most important techniques for avoiding crashes under snowy or icy conditions.

questions.question: When driving in work zones, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get through the zone as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed and be prepared to stop suddenly.
questions.answerC: Maintain your normal speed the whole way through the zone.
questions.explanation: When entering and driving through a work zone, slow down and be prepared to stop. Obey posted speed limits and be alert to conditions around you. Workers could be present.

questions.question: Smoking and preparing to smoke while driving:
questions.answerB: Help maintain driver alertness.
questions.answerC: Are distracting activities.
questions.explanation: Smoking while driving can create dangerous distractions by causing you to take your hands off the wheel and/or your eyes off the road.

questions.question: If your car's suspension is bad, it can cause:
questions.answerB: Squealing brakes.
questions.answerC: Slack in the steering.
questions.explanation: Your suspension helps you control your vehicle and provides a comfortable ride over varying road surfaces. If your vehicle bounces a lot after driving over a bump, or is generally hard to control, you may need new suspension parts.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on the road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a series of curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming winding road.

questions.question: If two drivers arrive at the same time to a four-way intersection controlled by stop signs:
questions.answerA: The driver on the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver may continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should honk to indicate that they are giving up the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: Yield the right-of-way to the driver on your right at a four-way intersection if you both arrive to the intersection at the same time. You may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Never drive a vehicle through, around, or under any railroad gate or barrier.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Never drive through, around, or under gates or barriers at a railroad crossing. It is illegal and very dangerous.

questions.question: Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian who is:
questions.answerB: In any crosswalk or intersection.
questions.answerC: Crossing any street.
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians who are crossing the street in any marked or unmarked crosswalk. In the interest of safety, drivers should yield the right-of-way to people crossing any street.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beam headlights may cause the light to reflect off of the fog and into your eyes.

questions.question: When you need to change lanes, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Signal your intentions ahead of the lane change.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Make sure the lane is clear before entering.
questions.explanation: Always signal for an appropriate amount of time before making a lane change or exiting a freeway. Before you make any move to the right or left, quickly turn your head and look over your shoulder to see if your blind spot is clear.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must drive slowly and sound your horn.
questions.answerB: A bus stop is ahead.
questions.answerC: You are entering a school's parking lot.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching a school zone and that they should slow down and watch for children.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Side road entering from left.
questions.answerC: Stop sign ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a yield sign ahead. You should begin to slow down when you see this warning sign.

questions.question: When approaching a four-way stop, drivers must yield the right-of-way to all motorists who arrived before them.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: At a four-way stop, you must yield the right-of-way to drivers who arrived before you. Wait your turn to enter the intersection.

questions.question: If you are getting tired while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and either get rest or change drivers.
questions.answerB: Drink something with caffeine.
questions.answerC: Open a window.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of fatigued driving, take breaks every hour or so during a long trip. If possible, share driving responsibilities with another person so you can each sleep while the other person drives.

questions.question: You can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by:
questions.answerA: Driving 10 mph faster than the car behind you.
questions.answerB: Driving 10 mph slower than the car behind you.
questions.answerC: Maintaining a steady speed.
questions.explanation: It is not always easy to maintain a safe distance behind your vehicle. However, you can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by maintaining a steady speed and signaling turns, lane changes, and deceleration in advance.

questions.question: Which is not a factor in determining the distance that it takes to stop your vehicle?
questions.answerB: Braking distance
questions.answerC: Reaction distance
questions.explanation: The distance required to stop your vehicle depends on perception time, reaction distance, and braking distance. This changes with speed and road conditions.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerB: Trucks use second gear
questions.answerC: Steep hill
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that you are approaching a steep hill. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: The most effective safety restraints in a traffic crash are:
questions.answerA: Only a lap and shoulder belt.
questions.answerB: Only an airbag.
questions.answerC: Both a lap/shoulder belt and an airbag.
questions.explanation: Safety belts can double your chance of surviving a crash and more than double your chance of avoiding serious injury. Airbags, when used properly with safety belts, provide additional protection in a front-end crash. You should wear both shoulder and lap belts.

questions.question: Signs that are colored orange are:
questions.answerB: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerC: School zone signs.
questions.explanation: Highway work zones are established according to the type of work underway along the roadway. Signs in work areas are typically diamond-shaped, orange, have black letters or symbols, and serve as a warning that people are working on or near the highway.

questions.question: At intersections with a "Yield" sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is near enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way only to vehicles on your right.
questions.answerC: Always slow down and proceed without stopping.
questions.explanation: At a yield sign, you must slow down or stop, if necessary, and give the right-of-way to crossing or merging vehicles. Yield the right-of-way to any cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.

questions.question: In traffic moving at 50 to 55 mph, you are least likely to have an accident if you:
questions.answerA: Drive a few miles per hour faster than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Stay within that speed range.
questions.answerC: Drive a few miles per hour slower than most other vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should adjust your speed to travel smoothly with the other traffic on a roadway (provided that the other traffic is driving within the posted speed limits). Remember that vehicles moving in the same direction at the same speed cannot hit each other. Crashes involving multiple vehicles often happen when some vehicles are traveling at different speeds than others.

questions.question: You should drive on the shoulder to pass a car:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle ahead of you is turning left.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: If the shoulder is wide enough.
questions.explanation: Passing on the right is permissible only if it is possible to do so without driving off the roadway. Never pass another vehicle on the shoulder because the other driver will not expect you to be there and may pull off the road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Exit.
questions.answerD: Sharp right turn in the road ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a sharp right turn ahead.

questions.question: A traffic light displaying a green arrow and a red light means that:
questions.answerA: You may only drive straight ahead.
questions.answerB: You may drive only in the direction of the green arrow.
questions.answerC: You must wait for a solid green light to proceed in any direction.
questions.answerD: Vehicles moving in any direction must stop.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow is shown with a red light, you can only drive in the direction of the arrow and only if the intersection is clear.

questions.question: Which of the following are used on some highways to direct drivers into the proper lanes for turning?
questions.answerB: Flashing yellow lights
questions.answerC: White lines on the side of the road
questions.answerD: White arrows in the middle of the lanes
questions.explanation: Arrows may be used to indicate which lanes should be used for specific purposes, such as driving straight or making a turn.

questions.question: On the freeway, you see a "Merging traffic“ sign. You should:
questions.answerB: Always remain at your present speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up to avoid congesting traffic.
questions.answerD: Move to another lane, if safe, to let traffic enter.
questions.explanation: When on a roadway with two or more lanes, you should make room for entering vehicles. If there is no one driving next to you, move over one lane.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady green arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn in the direction of the arrow after yielding to traffic and pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerD: May drive straight through the intersection.
questions.explanation: A green arrow displayed on a traffic signal tells drivers that they may turn in the direction of the arrow. You must be in the proper lane for such a turn. Yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians already in the intersection.

questions.question: Construction zone signs are generally:
questions.answerA: Square or rectangular with white and red coloring.
questions.answerB: Round or octagonal with black and yellow coloring.
questions.answerC: Diamond-shaped or rectangular with orange and black coloring.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have an orange background with black letters or symbols. These signs are found on the right side of the road, or on both the left and right sides if the roadway is a divided highway.

questions.question: Use your headlights on rainy, snowy, or foggy days:
questions.answerB: So others can see your vehicle.
questions.answerC: To warn others of bad weather conditions.
questions.explanation: On rainy, snowy, or foggy days, it may be difficult for other drivers to see your vehicle. Under these conditions, headlights make your vehicle easier to see. If the weather requires you to turn on your windshield wipers, you must also turn on your low beam headlights.

questions.question: Crosswalks are:
questions.answerA: Always indicated by horizontal pavement markings.
questions.answerB: Always indicated by vertical pavement markings.
questions.answerC: Always unmarked.
questions.answerD: Either indicated by pavement markings or not marked at all.
questions.explanation: Crosswalks exist whether the boundaries are marked or unmarked. You must stop behind the crosswalk to allow any pedestrians to cross.

questions.question: You should honk your horn when you:
questions.answerB: Are passing a bicyclist.
questions.answerC: See a child who is about to run into the street.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used as a warning in situations where you think another driver or a pedestrian does not see you. For example, if a child begins to run into the street in front of your vehicle, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: When making a right turn on a green light, you must:
questions.answerB: Stop and look for nearby police cars.
questions.answerC: Yield to pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign prohibits it, you may turn right or left at a steady green light. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: The presence of double solid yellow lines means you may pass another vehicle from either direction.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line means that it is prohibited for vehicles traveling in either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly cut across traffic to make your turn.
questions.answerB: Turn on your blinker and make the turn from your current lane.
questions.answerC: Drive to the next intersection and make your turn then.
questions.answerD: Safely change lanes then put your vehicle in reverse to go back to the intersection.
questions.explanation: Never make last-minute turns. If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane to make the turn, drive to the next intersection and then make the turn from the proper lane.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait until it is safe to do so, then gradually re-enter the roadway.
questions.answerB: Turn back onto the roadway immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, do not attempt to turn back onto the roadway immediately. Instead, reduce your speed, check traffic, and gradually turn back onto the roadway when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: On a multilane road, a dashed yellow line next to a solid yellow line means:
questions.answerA: Passing is prohibited from both directions.
questions.answerB: Passing is permitted from both directions.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted only from the direction next to the dashed line.
questions.explanation: Where there are both solid and dashed yellow lines between lanes of traffic, only traffic directly next to the dashed line may cross the centerline to pass. Drivers next to the solid line may not pass.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and use your brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly and quickly.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, you should slow down gradually by taking your foot off of the accelerator. Don't apply the brakes until the vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus that is stopped on the opposite side of a divided highway, drivers:
questions.answerB: Must stop until the school bus begins moving.
questions.answerC: Must stop until the stop arm is lifted.
questions.answerD: Must stop and wait for the flashing lights to stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a school bus that is stopped on the opposite side of a divided highway with its lights flashing and its stop arm extended, drivers may continue driving. If the highway is not separated by a median or divider, drivers on both sides of the street must stop.

questions.question: You are driving on a narrow road when you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
questions.answerA: Pull completely off the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Allow the oncoming vehicle at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road.
questions.answerC: Demand the other vehicle pull over to make room.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights to make sure the other vehicle sees you.
questions.explanation: On narrow roads, you must allow vehicles traveling in the opposite direction at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road. Both vehicles must have adequate space in order for the drivers to safely pass one another.

questions.question: A broken yellow line down the center of a road indicates that:
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: When broken yellow lines separate the lanes of traffic on a two-lane roadway, any driver may pass when there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You come to an intersection with a flashing red light. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive carefully through the  intersection.
questions.answerB: Turn either right or left, since the road is blocked ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop at the intersection and wait for a flashing green light.
questions.answerD: Stop at the intersection, then proceed as traffic allows.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must come to a full stop, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: When driving in bad weather, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Increase their speed to reach their final destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Decrease their following distance.
questions.answerC: Increase their following distance.
questions.explanation: When driving on wet roads, drivers should increase their following distance.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the maximum speed limit on a public highway is:
questions.answerB: 30 mph.
questions.answerC: 45 mph.
questions.explanation: When driving on a public highway, the maximum speed limit is 55 miles per hour. If a different speed limit is posted, follow the posted speed limit.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: In a curve or on a hill because the chance is small that another vehicle is coming.
questions.answerB: By using the shoulder of the highway.
questions.answerC: If your lane is next to a solid yellow line and the passing lane is clear ahead.
questions.explanation: You may not pass another vehicle on a hill or in a curve because you cannot see oncoming traffic and may cause a collision. Never pass another vehicle by driving onto the shoulder of a highway. Passing another vehicle by driving over a solid yellow line is prohibited.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Drive only in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerC: Curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. Where this sign is present, drivers must drive in the direction indicated by the arrow.

questions.question: You must not drive your vehicle at a speed greater than:
questions.answerB: A speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent.
questions.answerC: A speed that is safe for existing conditions.
questions.explanation: You must not drive at a speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent. You must drive at a speed that is appropriate for the area where you are driving, the type and condition of surrounding traffic, the presence of pedestrians, the weather, the quality of the road, and light conditions. You must drive within legal speed limits.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: The term “distracted driving” refers to driving while anything takes your eyes, hands, or mind away from the task at hand. Distracted driving is the most common contributing factor to reported traffic collisions. Distractions of any sort cause drivers to miss key visual and audio cues needed to avoid a crash.

questions.question: If a flagger is directing traffic in a construction zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the flagger.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the flagger's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the flagger is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow the laws that would be in place if the area was not under construction.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, flagger, or law enforcement officer. Failure to do so is illegal and is dangerous to those working in construction zones.

questions.question: When approaching a flashing red traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Drive through the intersection if there is no crossing traffic.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Stop if a police officer is nearby.
questions.answerD: Treat the light like a stop sign.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights are used at dangerous intersections. Treat them like stop signs.

questions.question: Consuming which of the following substances may impair your ability to drive safely and may result in an arrest for driving under the influence of intoxicants (DUII)?
questions.answerB: Controlled substances, such as illegal drugs or prescription medicines
questions.answerC: Inhalants, such as glue or paint
questions.explanation: A wide variety of intoxicants can impair your ability to drive. These include all types of alcoholic beverages, illegal drugs, inhalants, and many legal medications (both prescription and over-the-counter).

questions.question: When driving in fog or mist, never put your headlights on the high beam setting because:
questions.answerA: The light will reflect back into your eyes.
questions.answerB: Approaching vehicles might not see you.
questions.answerC: Vehicles behind you may follow too closely.
questions.explanation: In foggy or misty conditions, you should not use your headlights on their high beam setting because the light will be reflected back into your eyes.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign means that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: If a traffic signal light is green and a police officer signals for you to stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Obey the traffic signal.
questions.answerC: Do what the vehicle in front of you does.
questions.explanation: Drivers must obey any instructions given by a police officer, even if the instructions contradict laws, signs, signals, or markings that would otherwise apply.

questions.question: When approaching a flashing yellow light, drivers should:
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Turn on their headlights.
questions.answerD: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light warns of a hazard. Slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: What is the meaning of this sign?
questions.answerA: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a red light.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal ahead is broken.
questions.answerC: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a green light.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal at the intersection ahead.

questions.question: If you are being passed in a no passing zone, you should:
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and position.
questions.answerC: Slow down and let the other driver safely return to the drive lane.
questions.explanation: Passing areas are based on how far ahead drivers can see. Allow the passing vehicle to re-enter the drive lane as easily as possible to help everyone avoid potential upcoming hazards.

questions.question: You are merging onto an interstate highway. You should:
questions.answerA: Select a safe gap and merge into the lane of traffic.
questions.answerB: Merge across two lanes at once.
questions.answerC: Always stop before entering the highway.
questions.explanation: Anytime you want to merge with other drivers, you need to find a gap large enough for you to safely enter into the flow of traffic. You should not stop on the entrance ramp to an interstate highway unless there are no gaps into which you may safely merge.

questions.question: When completing an emergency roadside stop, it is not necessary to put on your parking brake.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Set your parking brake when making an emergency roadside stop. Turn on your emergency flashers to alert other drivers to your presence.

questions.question: You may turn right on red:
questions.answerA: If there is a sign prohibiting turning right on red.
questions.answerB: Before pedestrians have crossed any intersecting crosswalks.
questions.answerC: Before coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: After coming to a complete stop and yielding to pedestrians and vehicles in the intersection.
questions.explanation: At an intersection with a solid red traffic signal, you may turn right after coming to a full stop. You may only turn if it is safe to do so and if there is no sign prohibiting turns on a red light. Be careful of pedestrians crossing in front of your vehicle.

questions.question: While driving on a roadway with a single broken white centerline:
questions.answerA: You must stay within your lane.
questions.answerB: You may cross the centerline to change lanes.
questions.answerC: You may change lanes only from the left lane.
questions.explanation: White lines between lanes indicate that the lanes are traveling in the same direction. Broken white line markings indicate that it is legal to pass another vehicle when safe.

questions.question: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Grip the steering wheel firmly, slow down, and exit the traffic lane.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes rapidly.
questions.answerC: Brake hard and steer toward the right edge of the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you experience a sudden tire blowout, do not panic. Grasp the steering wheel firmly and take your foot off the accelerator to allow the vehicle to roll to a stop. Lightly apply the breaks when it is safe to do so. Do not move to the shoulder of the road until the car has slowed considerably.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about the presence of traffic signals at an intersection ahead.

questions.question: You want to back out of your driveway. You see children playing nearby. Before you start to move your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Rev your engine to warn the children that you are moving.
questions.answerB: Sound your horn so the children will hear you.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the car to be sure the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Tell the children to stay away from the driveway.
questions.explanation: When you back up a vehicle, look through your back window for pedestrians and other obstacles. Do not rely only on your mirrors, especially when children are near. Before you back into or out of a driveway, get out of the vehicle and check behind your vehicle.

questions.question: "No passing zone" signs tell drivers:
questions.answerB: That it is not safe to pass.
questions.answerC: To maintain a steady speed.
questions.explanation: If you come across a "No passing zone" sign, it is not legal to pass in the indicated area. You are likely driving in an area with restricted visibility where it would be unsafe to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: The effect that lack of sleep has on your safe driving ability is the same as:
questions.answerB: The effect that amphetamines have.
questions.answerC: The effect that anger has.
questions.answerD: The effect that driving with teenagers has.
questions.explanation: Fatigue and being under the influence of alcohol have similar effects on your ability to drive safely. For example, being awake for 18 hours impairs your driving about as much as a blood alcohol level of 0.05 percent. Being awake for 24 hours in a row has the same effect on your driving as a blood alcohol level of 0.10 percent.

questions.question: When exiting a highway, you should slow down:
questions.answerA: On the main road, just before the exit lane.
questions.answerB: Once you see a toll booth.
questions.answerC: Once you have moved into the exit lane.
questions.answerD: When you first see the exit sign.
questions.explanation: When exiting a highway, you should get into the exit lane well in advance. Do not begin to slow down until after you have moved into the exit lane.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection with a side road ahead.

questions.question: Worn or bald tires:
questions.answerB: Are likely to hydroplane.
questions.answerC: Can increase your stopping distance.
questions.explanation: Worn or bald tires can increase your stopping distance and make turning more difficult. Tires without adequate tread also increase the risk of hydroplaning.

questions.question: To know where traffic is behind you:
questions.answerB: Turn and look out your back window.
questions.answerC: Keep other vehicles out of your blind spots.
questions.explanation: Drivers should check their rearview mirrors often to stay aware of the position of traffic behind them.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates the presence of a crosswalk, regardless of if it is marked on the pavement or not. Upon seeing this sign, you should be alert and allow any pedestrians to cross the road safely.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds in a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Traffic increases ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the roadway will be slippery when wet and they should reduce their speed accordingly.

questions.question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking downhill, turn your front wheels toward the curb or edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road without a curb, turn your wheels toward the edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, you must turn your front wheels away from the curb.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must not cross here.
questions.answerD: Be alert for construction workers on the road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. Drivers should be cautious when driving where pedestrians may be present.

questions.question: On long trips, you can prevent drowsiness by:
questions.answerB: Slowing down.
questions.answerC: Stopping at regular intervals for a rest.
questions.answerD: Moving your eyes from side to side as you drive.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on long trips, you should schedule regular stops. Give yourself time to rest and stretch, even if you are not feeling tired.

questions.question: Using a cell phone while operating a motor vehicle is considered a distraction because:
questions.answerA: It causes the driver to be concerned about the cost of the call.
questions.answerB: It occupies the driver's hands, eyes, and mind.
questions.answerC: It is an activity that draws the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone while driving is dangerous because it occupies the user's eyes, hands, and mind. Even the most skilled drivers increase their risk of being involved in a crash by using a cell phone on the road.

questions.question: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to avoid the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle immediately and prevent them from passing.
questions.answerC: Make every effort to give the emergency vehicle a clear path of travel.
questions.answerD: Signal to the emergency vehicle when it is clear for them to pass you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you must make every effort to give them a clear path of travel. If it is safe to do so, pull your vehicle to the side of the road to give the emergency vehicle an open pathway.

questions.question: If two drivers arrive at the same time to an open intersection:
questions.answerA: The driver on the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver may continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should honk to indicate that they are giving up the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If you arrive to an open intersection at the same time as a vehicle to your right, you should yield the right-of-way to that vehicle. You may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A sign with this shape means:
questions.answerB: Warning.
questions.answerC: Signal ahead.
questions.explanation: A diamond-shaped yellow sign warns of possible danger ahead. Orange signs, which are mostly diamond-shaped, are used to warn of possible dangers in or near work areas.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that passing is:
questions.answerA: Permitted from the side next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Permitted from the side next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: When the center of the road is marked by a solid yellow line beside a broken yellow line, passing is permitted from the side next to the broken line and prohibited from the side next to the solid line.

questions.question: When stopping on snow or ice, drivers who are operating vehicles equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should:
questions.answerB: Press and hold the brake pedal firmly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes and wait for the car to drift to a stop.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), a driver should press the brake pedal firmly when stopping on a snowy or icy surface. The ABS will pump the brakes more rapidly than a driver would be able to.

questions.question: Night driving presents unique problems because:
questions.answerA: The speed limit is increased at night.
questions.answerB: There are fewer cars on the roads at night.
questions.answerC: Distance and vehicle speed are difficult to judge in the dark.
questions.explanation: Night driving creates a unique set of problems for drivers. Due to the reduced visibility, it can be difficult to judge distance and the traveling speeds of other vehicles when driving at night. Drivers can see only as far as their headlights allow.

questions.question: Highway markings:
questions.answerB: Are only found in construction zones.
questions.answerC: Provide information for drivers.
questions.answerD: Are usually red and blue in color.
questions.explanation: Highway markings provide information for drivers. Markings help drivers correctly position their vehicles on roadways, inform drivers of safe passing zones, and warn drivers about upcoming conditions.

questions.question: This yellow sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a sharp turn to the right.
questions.answerB: The lane must turn right.
questions.answerC: A right turn is permitted on a green arrow only.
questions.explanation: Some warning signs have a fluorescent yellow-green background. These signs warn of upcoming conditions, including roads with curves and sharp turns.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign is a:
questions.answerB: Interstate route sign.
questions.answerC: School crossing sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are normally diamond-shaped and yellow, although orange warning signs are used in work areas. Such signs warn that you are approaching a hazardous location or an area where special rules apply.

questions.question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, what should the motorist do?
questions.answerA: Continue ahead. The motorist has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Wait for the pedestrians to cross the street.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and go around the pedestrians.
questions.explanation: A driver must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian within a crosswalk. The driver should wait until the intersection is clear to proceed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a steep hill ahead.

questions.question: Changing from one lane to another is best done:
questions.answerB: When a car is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Gradually and carefully.
questions.explanation: You should always change lanes gradually and carefully. Only change lanes when necessary. Every lane change increases the possibility of a traffic accident.

questions.question: Where is it safe to pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: Within an intersection where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.answerB: Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing
questions.answerC: Within a curve where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.explanation: Never pass within intersections or at other intersecting points, such as parking lot entrances and alleyways. Any time your view is blocked by a curve or a hill, you should stay in your lane and assume that there is an oncoming vehicle just out of sight. Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing other vehicles, you will have to determine whether or not you have enough space to pass in a safe manner.

questions.question: If you come to a railroad crossing with lowered gates and flashing warning lights, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive around the crossing gates if you can't see a train.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop well behind the gates, wait for the tracks to clear, and proceed once the gates are lifted.
questions.answerC: Slow down and drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing where signs, warning devices, or flaggers warn you of the presence of a train. It is illegal to drive around lowered gates.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Railroad warning.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn can be made here.
questions.answerB: A left turn can be made only after stopping.
questions.answerC: All traffic must turn right at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: Signs with a red circle and diagonal line over a black symbol indicate that the action represented by the symbol is prohibited. In this case, the sign indicates that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your low beam headlights:
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: You should always use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beam headlights may cause the light to reflect off of the fog and into your eyes.

questions.question: If you need to stop quickly and your vehicle is not equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerB: Firmly pump your brakes.
questions.answerC: Lightly tap the brakes.
questions.explanation: Pumping the brakes is generally the best way to stop a car in an emergency. The car will stop quickly and you will also be able to continue steering.

questions.question: Pennant-shaped signs indicate:
questions.answerB: No passing zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped signs usually indicate no passing zones. Text will also be on the sign to confirm that it is a no passing zone.

questions.question: If another driver cuts you off in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull next to the driver and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Let it go.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams at the driver.
questions.answerD: Get back at the other driver by cutting them off.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of road rage, you should never take it personally if another driver cuts you off in traffic. Just let it go and continue driving safely.

questions.question: You must stop at an intersection when you see a:
questions.answerB: Steady yellow light.
questions.answerC: Yellow arrow.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. At an intersection with a flashing red light, you must come to a complete stop, look both ways, and proceed only after the intersection is clear.

questions.question: A solid yellow arrow on a traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: You should speed up so you can make the turn before the light changes.
questions.answerB: You do not need to signal to turn from the indicated lane.
questions.answerC: You should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow arrow means that the protection of a green arrow is ending. If you are turning in the direction of the arrow, you should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic before turning.

questions.question: A motorist making a left turn at an intersection must yield the right-of-way to a bicyclist entering the intersection from the opposite direction.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, you must yield to oncoming bicycles in the same manner that you would yield to oncoming motor vehicles. Keep your wheels straight while waiting to turn and proceed when the way is clear of traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: Check your rearview mirrors:
questions.answerA: Often to see how traffic is moving behind you.
questions.answerB: To see if a vehicle is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Only when you are slowing down.
questions.explanation: When driving, do not develop a fixed stare. Frequently check your rearview mirrors so you know the positions of vehicles near you.

questions.question: When driving in fog:
questions.answerB: Use your low beams.
questions.answerC: Use your high beams.
questions.answerD: It makes no difference which lights you use.
questions.explanation: You should use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection and your view to the side is blocked, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and look both ways.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and look both ways.
questions.answerC: Stop, then inch forward until you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.explanation: Drivers must slow down when approaching an intersection. If a clear view of cross traffic is obscured, a driver should come to a stop and inch forward until they can see clearly in both directions.

questions.question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Always check your blind spots before moving back into your original lane.

questions.question: If you need to drive in foggy weather:
questions.answerA: Turn on your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights.
questions.answerC: It is okay to drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerD: Do not drive at a speed above 10 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: You are required to use your headlights during the day when visibility is reduced to 500 feet or less. When you first turn on your headlights, be sure they are adjusted to the low beam setting. Using high beams in fog or rain will cause the light to reflect back into your eyes, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: You should always travel:
questions.answerA: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you.
questions.answerB: At the speed limit.
questions.answerC: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you should drive your vehicle depends on road conditions, the weather, and the legal speed limit. You may never drive above the legal speed limit. Decrease your speed when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume all drivers automatically obey the right-of-way rules.
questions.answerB: Assume most drivers obey the right-of-way rules.
questions.answerC: Always be prepared to yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: Although the right-of-way rules provide a guide to determine who should yield the right-of-way at an intersection, no one should assume they automatically have the right-of-way. The situation and circumstances at an intersection must always be considered. Drivers should yield their legal right-of-way if it can help prevent a collision.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerB: Open your window.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: What does a lane use control signal displaying a green arrow above a reversible lane indicate?
questions.answerA: The signal is about to change to a red X.
questions.answerB: Drivers should not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: Drivers may use this lane only to make a left turn.
questions.answerD: Drivers may drive normally in this lane.
questions.explanation: Lane use control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. When a lane control signal contains a green arrow, drivers may drive normally in the indicated lane.

questions.question: When dealing with pedestrians, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian is aware of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Always yield the right-of-way, even if the pedestrian is in the wrong.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way only when the pedestrian is legally entitled to it.
questions.answerD: Slow down and sound their horn near a crosswalk.
questions.explanation: You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian or another vehicle, regardless of the circumstances. It is the driver’s basic responsibility to be alert to pedestrians and to yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians, even if the pedestrian is crossing the street where they should not be.

questions.question: Which of the following must you obey over the other three?
questions.answerB: A police officer
questions.answerC: A stop sign
questions.explanation: Directions given by traffic officers take precedence over signs, signals, and pavement markings. People authorized to direct traffic include police officers, fire police, highway work area flag persons, and school crossing persons.

questions.question: If you see this sign, you:
questions.answerB: May pass a slow-moving vehicle if you can do so quickly.
questions.answerC: May pass if you know the road ahead.
questions.answerD: May pass, but only at night.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are white, rectangular signs with black markings. Drivers must obey the instructions posted on all regulatory signs. Where this sign is posted, it is prohibited for drivers to pass one another.

questions.question: A flashing red traffic light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: The same thing as a yield sign.
questions.answerB: The light is about to turn green.
questions.answerC: The same thing as a stop sign.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light at an intersection means drivers are required to come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when the way is clear. The same is true at a stop sign.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This signs indicate that U-turns are prohibited in the location where it is posted.

questions.question: Reduce your speed when:
questions.answerB: There is dense fog.
questions.answerC: It is raining.
questions.explanation: The maximum speed limit should be driven only under ideal conditions. You must reduce your speed when safety requires it, such as during snowy, icy, rainy, or foggy weather.

questions.question: If someone is driving aggressively behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of the aggressive driver’s way.
questions.answerB: Stare at the driver as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerC: Speed up as he or she is passing you.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should make every attempt to get out of their way. You should avoid making eye contact with a hostile driver. Challenging a hostile driver by speeding up may only make them angrier, thereby increasing their danger.

questions.question: If you stop along the road at night:
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights only.
questions.answerC: Use your headlights only.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams turned on.
questions.explanation: If you stop along the road at night, turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beam headlights turned on. Be sure that other road users will be able to clearly see your vehicle.

questions.question: Allow a larger space cushion than usual when stopping:
questions.answerB: At an intersection.
questions.answerC: At a stop sign.
questions.explanation: You should allow more space in front of your vehicle than usual when you are stopped on an uphill slope. If the vehicle in front of you rolls backward toward your vehicle when traffic begins to move again, it is less likely that there will be a collision.

questions.question: Emergency vehicles:
questions.answerA: Have the right-of-way when using sirens, horns, and/or flashing lights.
questions.answerB: May use a loudspeaker to give instructions.
questions.answerC: May follow each other.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to police cars, fire engines, ambulances, or any other emergency vehicles using a siren or air horn and a red or blue flashing light. Follow any instructions given over the emergency vehicles' loudspeakers. Emergency vehicles often follow each other so you should proceed only when you are certain the way is clear.

questions.question: Your body gets rid of approximately:
questions.answerB: One alcoholic drink an hour.
questions.answerC: Two alcoholic drinks an hour.
questions.explanation: The average person’s body will process about one alcoholic drink in one hour. However, many factors play a part in determining how impaired a person will become when consuming alcohol, including the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast it is consumed, and a person’s body weight, food intake, and general health.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right ahead.
questions.answerB: Upcoming sharp left and right turns.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns the driver that there is an upcoming winding road. Speed should be adjusted appropriately.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross in front of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrian.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the pedestrian cross.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop whenever you see pedestrians walking on or crossing the roadway. Be particularly careful where children are present. Always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing in a crosswalk.

questions.question: It is illegal for a vehicle to drive on a sidewalk, except to cross it.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Drivers crossing a sidewalk entering or exiting a driveway, alley, or parking lot must yield to pedestrians. It is illegal to drive on a sidewalk, except to cross it.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull off the right side of the road and let traffic pass.
questions.answerC: Not let the other cars pass your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: No turn on red.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. The road will split into two one-way roadways separated by a median or divider. You must keep to the right.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Signal at least 100 feet before changing lanes to pass and ensure there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors and look over your left shoulder to check your blind spot when passing to the left.
questions.answerC: When passing, wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.
questions.explanation: When passing, you must always signal at least 100 feet in advance of your lane change. Always check behind you in your mirrors and look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop, if necessary.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided sign always means "stop." You must come to a complete stop and wait for any vehicles or pedestrians to clear the way before proceeding.

questions.question: You are driving behind a motorcycle and want to pass. You must:
questions.answerA: Stay in the right lane as much as possible because the motorcycle is small and doesn't use all of the lane.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn to make the motorcycle move onto the shoulder so that you can pass.
questions.answerC: Have your vehicle entirely in the left lane before and during the pass.
questions.explanation: When passing a motorcycle, allow a full lane to the motorcycle. Never crowd into the same lane as the motorcycle. Returning to the original lane too soon can force a rider to swerve to the right and into traffic or off the road.

questions.question: HOV lanes are reserved for:
questions.answerB: Motorcycles.
questions.answerC: Government vehicles.
questions.explanation: “HOV” stands for “High Occupancy Vehicles.” HOV lanes are reserved for vehicles with more than one occupant. Signs indicate how many people must be in the vehicle, as well as the days and hours during which the restriction applies.

questions.question: If worried, nervous, angry, or crying, a driver:
questions.answerA: Will drive no differently than they would if they were thinking more clearly.
questions.answerB: Can drive faster because they are more in touch with their senses.
questions.answerC: Should take the time to focus on driving before starting the engine.
questions.answerD: Should call a friend to vent while driving.
questions.explanation: You may not be able to drive well if you are worried, excited, crying, angry, or depressed. Emotions can distract you from your driving because your mind is focused on something else. Take time to calm down and get focused before driving.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of of an approaching traffic signal.

questions.question: If you drive faster than other vehicles on a road with one lane moving in each direction and continually pass the other cars, you will:
questions.answerA: Get you to your destination much more quickly and safely.
questions.answerB: Increase your chances of an collision.
questions.answerC: Help prevent traffic congestion.
questions.explanation: You should avoid passing other vehicles on two-lane roads. Every time you pass a vehicle, your odds of being in a collision increase.

questions.question: You want to turn left at an intersection. The light is green but oncoming traffic is heavy. You should:
questions.answerB: Wait at the crosswalk for traffic to clear.
questions.answerC: Wait in the center of the intersection for traffic to clear.
questions.answerD: Take the right-of-way since you have a green light.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn where there is approaching traffic, you must wait for the approaching traffic to go through before you turn. You may enter the intersection to prepare for your left turn if the light is green and no other vehicle ahead of you plans to make a left turn.

questions.question: What should you do when you are going to enter a roadway from a private road?
questions.answerA: Blow your horn to warn cars you are entering the roadway.
questions.answerB: Stop with part of your car on the roadway to alert other drivers.
questions.answerC: Drive out fast to merge smoothly with the traffic.
questions.answerD: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a roadway from a driveway or private road, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and traffic on the roadway.

questions.question: You notice that the driver in the vehicle ahead of you is driving with one hand and talking to a passenger. You should:
questions.answerB: Know that the driver in the vehicle ahead is reducing their safety margin by being an inattentive driver.
questions.answerC: Avoid following the driver's example.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. If a driver near you seems distracted, allow them extra space because the risk of an accident is increased by their inattentiveness.

questions.question: A solid yellow line next to a broken yellow line means that vehicles:
questions.answerA: Driving in both directions may pass.
questions.answerB: Next to the broken line may pass.
questions.answerC: Next to the solid line may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken yellow line next to your driving lane means that you may pass.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident. You should:
questions.answerB: Help the injured.
questions.answerC: Call the police.
questions.explanation: If involved in an accident, you should stop your vehicle immediately. If possible, move the vehicle out of the way of traffic. Call the nearest police agency and ask for an ambulance, if necessary. Do not move the injured unnecessarily, but attempt to stop severe bleeding with direct pressure. Wait for emergency vehicles to arrive.

questions.question: If you want to pass a pedestrian who is walking along the roadway and an oncoming vehicle is approaching, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass before you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Keep driving at a steady speed. The oncoming vehicle must stop for you.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to get the pedestrian to move over.
questions.explanation: If possible, try to only deal with one roadway hazard at a time. If you want to pass a pedestrian but an oncoming vehicle is approaching, slow down and let the vehicle pass. You may then pass the pedestrian if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign indicates a:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: Yellow signs with black markings are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazards or special conditions. Round signs are used only to warn about upcoming railroad crossings.

questions.question: The center of the roadway is marked with one solid yellow line and one broken yellow line. If the broken yellow line is directly next to your traffic lane, it means:
questions.answerA: You are not allowed to pass in this area.
questions.answerB: You are in a passing zone and it is safe for you to pass other vehicles on the left if no oncoming traffic is present.
questions.answerC: You are only allowed to make right turns in this area.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road, passing is permitted from the side of the road next to the broken line.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Use your left foot to brake.
questions.answerB: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You should always brake abruptly to ensure stopping.
questions.explanation: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating. You should apply the brakes gently with increasing pressure so that your vehicle stops gradually and smoothly.

questions.question: The speed limit in school zones is:
questions.answerB: 15 mph.
questions.answerC: 25 mph.
questions.explanation: The statewide speed limit in school zones is 15 miles per hour. Always drive with extra caution when driving in an area where you may encounter children or other pedestrians.

questions.question: You may not park within ____ of a crosswalk.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.answerC: 50 feet
questions.explanation: There are many areas where you cannot park. You may not park within 25 feet of a crosswalk or intersection.

questions.question: Round signs indicate:
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: Upcoming railroad crossings.
questions.explanation: Round signs warn drivers of an upcoming railroad crossing area. Drivers should use extra caution when approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: A driver does not need to allow as much distance when following a motorcycle as when following a car.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: In dry conditions, motorcycles can stop more quickly than cars. Therefore, a driver behind a motorcycle should allow at least three to four seconds of following distance so that the motorcyclist has time to maneuver in an emergency.

questions.question: You can drive off the road to pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle ahead is turning left.
questions.answerB: If there are two or more lanes traveling in your direction.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.explanation: You may never drive off the paved or main-traveled portion of the road and onto the shoulder to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: If pedestrians are illegally crossing in the middle of the street instead of in a crosswalk, you:
questions.answerB: Do not have to stop for them.
questions.answerC: Should honk your horn at them.
questions.explanation: You must yield to pedestrians at all times. If the pedestrians are jaywalking or crossing the street where they should not be, you must still stop for them.

questions.question: Continuous hard braking on ice and snow often:
questions.answerB: Locks the front wheels of a vehicle, causing a loss of steering.
questions.answerC: Keeps the brakes from freezing.
questions.explanation: Continuous hard braking on snow and ice can result in the locking of the front brake, causing a loss of steering. To avoid the need for excessive braking, make sure to maintain an appropriate speed for conditions.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: While driving, your wheels slip off the edge of the road. You should:
questions.answerA: Jerk the steering wheel to force the vehicle back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Speed up and steer back onto the pavement gradually.
questions.answerC: Slam on your brakes and stop.
questions.answerD: Slow down by gently using the brakes. Turn the steering wheel to return to the pavement at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to leave the road, continue to drive with the wheels off the pavement and reduce your speed by gently applying the brakes. When at a safe speed, turn the steering wheel to return to the pavement. Do not attempt to force your vehicle back onto the pavement by sharply turning the steering wheel.

questions.question: Drivers are not required to yield to pedestrians in a crosswalk.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: A driver must come to a complete stop and yield when a pedestrian is in a marked crosswalk. A driver must also yield to a pedestrian who is in an unmarked crosswalk on the driver’s side of the roadway when there are no traffic control signals.

questions.question: What does a lane use control signal displaying a solid yellow X above a reversible lane indicate?
questions.answerA: The signal is about to change to a red X.
questions.answerB: The signal is about to change to a green arrow.
questions.answerC: Drivers may drive normally in this lane.
questions.answerD: Drivers may drive slowly in this lane.
questions.explanation: Lane use control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. When a lane control signal contains a solid yellow X, drivers should clear the indicated lane, as the lane signal is about to change to a red X.

questions.question: It is very foggy. You should slow down and:
questions.answerB: Turn your lights to their high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights to their low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield just to the traffic on the right.
questions.answerC: Yield just to the traffic on the left.
questions.answerD: Slow down and yield the right-of-way to other traffic.
questions.explanation: A yield sign means that you must slow down and yield the right-of-way to traffic in the intersection or roadway you are entering.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerB: School crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.explanation: A downward-facing triangular sign is always a yield sign. Drivers must be prepared to slow down or stop when approaching a yield sign.

questions.question: When parallel parking between two cars, you should first:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerC: Pull up even with the car in front of your desired parking space.
questions.explanation: After finding a parking space, checking traffic, and signaling, you should stop parallel to the vehicle directly ahead of your desired parking space before turning your wheel to park.

questions.question: If you are turning onto a street with more than one lane traveling in your direction, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerB: Turn into the lane marked with an arrow.
questions.answerC: Turn into the middle lane.
questions.explanation: When turning onto a street with more than one lane moving in the direction that you are traveling, turn into the lane that is closest to your previous lane. Do not change lanes when turning.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane reduction. The right lane ends soon and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.explanation: A warning sign is usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the number of lanes ahead is reduced and that traffic will need to merge to the left.

questions.question: Drivers must be careful when passing large vehicles and should avoid driving beside large vehicles for long periods of time.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Because large vehicles have large blind spots on both sides, you should avoid driving beside a large vehicle for a long period of time. It is safest for you to either drop back or move forward when you find yourself directly next to a large vehicle.

questions.question: Interstate driving requires drivers to:
questions.answerA: Have the ability to safely drive at increased speeds.
questions.answerB: Be constantly alert.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Safe use of the interstate demands drivers be constantly alert and capable of driving at high speeds.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the maximum speed limit on a rural interstate highway is:
questions.answerB: 55 mph.
questions.answerC: 75 mph.
questions.explanation: When driving on a rural interstate highway, the maximum speed limit is 75 miles per hour. If a different speed limit is posted, follow the posted speed limit.

questions.question: When two vehicles arrive to an intersection at the same time, which one has the right-of-way when no signs or signals indicate rules?
questions.answerA: The car approaching from the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car approaching from the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car in which the driver sounds his horn first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: The car that is traveling the fastest has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: At an intersection of two similar roads without a traffic control device, a driver must yield to a vehicle approaching from the right.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when:
questions.answerA: Driving behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision.
questions.answerB: Exiting an expressway.
questions.answerC: Following a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should increase your following distance when you are behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision, when driving in bad weather or heavy traffic, when exiting an expressway, when behind a motorcycle or bicycle, and if someone is tailgating you.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about driving on a wet roadway?
questions.answerA: As you drive faster, your tires become less effective.
questions.answerB: Water does not affect cars with good tires.
questions.answerC: Deep water is less dangerous than shallow water.
questions.answerD: As you decrease your speed, the roadway becomes more slippery.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive on a wet roadway, the less effective your tires will be at wiping the water from the road. If your speed becomes excessive enough, your tires will lose their grip on the road entirely and you will begin to hydroplane (that is, to slide down the road on a film of water).

questions.question: Vehicle stopping distances never depend on:
questions.answerB: The time of day.
questions.answerC: The condition of your vehicle's brakes.
questions.answerD: The condition and type of your vehicle's tires.
questions.explanation: The distance that a vehicle needs to stop depends on the motorist's reaction time, weather and visibility conditions, the vehicle's weight, the conditions of the vehicle's brakes, the condition and type of the vehicle's tires, roadway conditions, and speed.

questions.question: You have allowed the wheels of your vehicle to run off the edge of the pavement. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels slightly to the left to edge the car back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes and turn the front wheels sharply to the left.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle leaves the roadway, hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes. Wait until your speed has reduced, check the traffic, and look for a place to safely return to the roadway by merging back into traffic. Overcompensating by jerking the wheel to return to the roadway can cause you to lose control of your vehicle or may cause your car to go into other lanes of traffic.

questions.question: What should you be most concerned about when you see this sign?
