questions.explanation: Drivers may not enter an intersection unless they can get through it without having to stop. In heavy traffic, wait until the vehicles ahead of you clear an intersection before you proceed so that you are not blocking the intersection when the light for cross traffic turns green.

questions.question: To avoid collisions with vehicles in your blind spots, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn your head to see if your blind spot is clear before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Adjust your rearview mirrors every few minutes.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn right before turning or changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Before turning or changing lanes, turn your head and glance over your shoulder in the direction of your move to see if your blind spot is clear. Never rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lane markings mean that:
questions.answerB: Both lanes may pass.
questions.answerC: The lane to the right may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lane markings indicate a separation of lanes where traffic is traveling in opposite directions. When you see double solid yellow lane markings, passing is prohibited from both directions.

questions.question: If you are driving on a one-way street and an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights approaches your vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Drive with your flashers turned on.
questions.answerB: Drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.answerD: Slow down until the vehicle passes you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its lights or siren approaches while you are driving on a one-way street, you must drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: You are waiting in the intersection to complete a left turn. You should:
questions.answerA: Signal and keep your wheels turned to the left.
questions.answerB: Signal and keep your wheels straight.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights so drivers will let you through.
questions.answerD: Drive around the rear of a car if it blocks you.
questions.explanation: You must always signal before turning or changing lanes. You should keep your wheels straight while waiting to make a left turn. If another vehicle hits you from behind, this ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Which is the most common cause of traffic crashes?
questions.answerB: Human error
questions.answerC: Bad weather
questions.explanation: Crashes often occur when one driver does not see another vehicle or when a driver does something unexpected. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent traffic crashes.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:
questions.answerB: Prevents rear-end collisions.
questions.answerC: Improves traffic flow by preventing collisions.
questions.explanation: Avoid "rubbernecking," or slowing down to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary. This helps to relieve traffic congestion.

questions.question: When stopped for a traffic violation or at an equipment check, the driver must produce:
questions.answerB: Their license.
questions.answerC: Proof of registration.
questions.explanation: When stopped for a traffic violation or at an equipment check, the driver is responsible for producing their license, proof of registration, and proof of insurance. Drivers are required to have all three of these documents in a vehicle when it is being driven.

questions.question: What should you do when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Look for a train station ahead.
questions.answerB: Signal before going any further.
questions.answerC: Slow down and yield to trains.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: It is illegal for a vehicle to drive on a sidewalk, except to cross it.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Drivers crossing a sidewalk entering or exiting a driveway, alley, or parking lot must yield to pedestrians. It is illegal to drive on a sidewalk, except to cross it.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Buggy warning.
questions.answerC: Limited parking.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that there is an upcoming stop sign and that they should prepare to come to a complete stop before proceeding.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: While driving, you come upon a sign displaying the words “Reduced speed, 35 mph." This means:
questions.answerA: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at this sign.
questions.answerB: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at the next speed limit sign.
questions.answerC: That you have plenty of time to slow down before the reduced speed zone.
questions.answerD: That you should reduce your speed to 35 mph, but only under poor weather conditions.
questions.explanation: "Reduced speed" signs inform drivers that they must reduce their speeds. If a new speed limit is posted on one of these signs, the new speed limit begins at the sign.

questions.question: HOV lanes are reserved for:
questions.answerB: Motorcycles.
questions.answerC: Government vehicles.
questions.explanation: “HOV” stands for “High Occupancy Vehicles.” HOV lanes are reserved for vehicles with more than one occupant. Signs indicate how many people must be in the vehicle, as well as the days and hours during which the restriction applies.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerB: Regulatory sign.
questions.answerC: Warning sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. There may be an upcoming change in traffic direction, a steep downgrade, or another potentially hazardous situation that requires action on the part of the driver.

questions.question: You may drive around the gates at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: When the lights have stopped flashing.
questions.answerD: When other drivers drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You are required to stop at all railroad crossings when signals warn of an approaching train. These signals may include flashing red lights, a lowered crossing gate, a flagger signaling, or a train’s audible signal of warning. Do not attempt to go around a lowered gate.

questions.question: Distracted driving may be caused by:
questions.answerB: Talking or texting on a cellular phone.
questions.answerC: Changing a radio station or CD.
questions.explanation: It is estimated that drivers make 200 decisions for every mile traveled, making it vital that drivers focus their full attention on the task of driving. Performing any additional task can create a dangerous distraction.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: U-turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: When should you drive in a reversible lane that is below a lane use control signal showing a red X?
questions.answerA: When there is no visible oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: When you are passing the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Never.
questions.explanation: Lane use control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. Never drive in a lane marked with a red X.

questions.question: If you can see that the roadway up ahead is covered by heavy smoke, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your four-way flashers and continue.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed, move as far to the right as possible, and stop off the roadway.
questions.answerC: Turn on your high beam headlights and continue.
questions.explanation: If you notice that the road ahead is covered by heavy smoke, reduce your speed immediately, drive as far as possible to the right, and stop off the roadway. Only then should you determine if it is safe for you to continue. Remember that certain kinds of smoke can irritate your eyes and lungs or even kill you.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal when changing lanes, pulling into or out of a parking space, or pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent accidents.

questions.question: At a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if:
questions.answerA: You first come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: You wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: You are in the proper lane and the roadway is clear.
questions.explanation: If you are in a lane corresponding to a signal displaying a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow when the way is clear. This is true whether the arrow is displayed alone or together with another signal.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: On a traffic signal arranged vertically, red is always on top and green on the bottom. When arranged horizontally, red is always on the left and green on the right.

questions.question: If you are driving and a tire suddenly goes flat, you should:
questions.answerA: Rapidly pump the brake pedal several times.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and not brake.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake pedal as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: If a tire blows out or suddenly goes flat while you are driving, grip the steering wheel firmly and keep the vehicle aiming straight. Take your foot off the accelerator and do not brake. Allow the vehicle to slow by itself and use the brakes gently, but only if necessary. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerB: Extremely risky behavior.
questions.answerC: Nothing to be concerned about.
questions.answerD: No less safe than driving under any other conditions.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is extremely risky behavior that puts not only you and your passengers in danger, but also endangers pedestrians, bicyclists, and other motorists sharing the road. Focused attention on driving helps to prevent crashes.

questions.question: When approaching a steady red traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Drive through the intersection if there is no crossing traffic.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Stop only if a police officer is nearby.
questions.explanation: A steady red traffic light indicates that drivers must come to a complete stop. Driving through a red light is against the law and is extremely dangerous. Drivers may turn right on a steady red light if there is no sign prohibiting a turn on red.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about changing lanes?
questions.answerA: You only need to turn and look over your right shoulder for lane changes to the right or left.
questions.answerB: Look over your right shoulder for a right lane change and your left shoulder for a left lane change.
questions.answerC: Vehicles with two outside mirrors do not have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, signal, look in all your mirrors, and look over your left or right shoulder to make sure the lane next to you is clear. Looking over your shoulder is a way to check your blind spot to be sure there is no vehicle, motorcycle, or bicycle traffic in the next lane.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about railroad crossings is true?
questions.answerA: It is against the law to go around lowered gates at a crossing.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerC: Not all railroad crossings are equipped with flashing red signals and gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning devices, such as gates or flashing lights. Not all railroad crossings are equipped with such devices. It is against the law to drive around lowered railroad crossing gates.

questions.question: Only vehicles displaying special plates or parking placards for persons with disabilities may park in spaces reserved for them by an official sign.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: A parking space marked by a "Reserved Parking for Persons with Disabilities" sign may only be used by vehicles that display Persons with Disabilities license plates, Disabled Veteran license plates, and/or disabled parking placards.

questions.question: Certain highway signs contain information about hazardous conditions. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Warning signs advise drivers of potentially hazardous conditions. For your own safety, obey warning signs. Disregarding the information provided by a warning sign may result in an accident due to your negligence.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to.
questions.answerB: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn.
questions.answerC: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb.
questions.explanation: If you try to insert your vehicle between a turning truck or bus and a curb, you may suffer a serious crash. To avoid a collision, do not turn until the truck or bus has completed its turn.

questions.question: What should a driver do when approaching a traffic control signal that is not in operation?
questions.answerA: Come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: If the intersection is clear, the driver does not need to stop.
questions.answerC: Drive quickly through the intersection to get out of the way of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When traffic control signals are not working, a driver must always treat the intersection as an all-way stop and come to a complete stop, unless otherwise directed by law enforcement. The driver must then look and yield the right-of-way before entering the intersection.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
questions.answerA: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerB: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving.
questions.answerC: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving.
questions.explanation: Legal prescription and over-the-counter drugs can impair your ability to drive, including drugs taken for colds, hay fever, allergies, or to calm nerves or muscles. It is illegal to drive while under the influence of any drug that impairs your ability to drive safely; this law does not differentiate between illegal, prescription, or over-the-counter drugs.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, you should:
questions.answerA: Be prepared for a person or vehicle to unexpectedly enter your lane.
questions.answerB: Expect all other drivers and pedestrians to respect your right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Drive closely to the parked vehicles to allow more room for moving traffic.
questions.explanation: Keep a space between your vehicle and parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between the parked vehicles without looking. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: If there is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian can see you before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Cautiously drive around the pedestrian.
questions.answerC: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in the roadway, even if there is not a marked crosswalk.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle, small children:
questions.answerA: May be safely held by a strong adult.
questions.answerB: Will be safe if they are standing on the floor in the back of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will not be hurt in an accident because they are small.
questions.answerD: Must never be allowed to ride while standing in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Special child seats are available for children who are too small to wear regular safety belts. No person is strong enough to safely hold onto a child of any size during an accident or sudden stop. Never allow a child to ride in a vehicle unless they are properly fastened into a seat.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No U-turns.
questions.answerC: No exit.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed at the beginning of one-way streets and ramps to indicate that you must not continue driving in your current direction.

questions.question: When may you drive on the right shoulder of the road?
questions.answerA: Only when told to do so by an official.
questions.answerB: When the car in front of you is driving too slowly.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is turning.
questions.explanation: If you pass another vehicle on its right, do so only when conditions permit you to do so legally and safely. You may only drive on the shoulder of a road if an official has directed you to do so.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross the street after the "Don't Walk" signal begins to flash. The pedestrian is in the middle of the street when your signal light changes to green. You should:
questions.answerA: Proceed if you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Proceed if the pedestrian is not in your lane.
questions.answerC: Wait until the pedestrian crosses the street before proceeding.
questions.explanation: At a green light, you must give the right-of-way to any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian in the intersection. If a pedestrian begins crossing the street after the traffic signal light starts flashing, wait until they have crossed the street before proceeding.

questions.question: An orange-colored sign like this means:
questions.answerB: You must change lanes ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a detour ahead.
questions.explanation: Orange-colored signs indicate construction areas. Proceed with caution.

questions.question: Road rage and aggressive driving may be reduced by:
questions.answerB: Obeying posted speed limits.
questions.answerC: Using proper turn signals.
questions.explanation: As an increasing number of drivers populate the roadways, road rage becomes more prevalent. To help prevent road rage, a driver should use proper turn signals, obey posted speed limits, and allow plenty of travel time.

questions.question: What does a lane use control signal displaying a green arrow above a reversible lane indicate?
questions.answerA: The signal is about to change to a red X.
questions.answerB: Drivers should not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: Drivers may use this lane only to make a left turn.
questions.answerD: Drivers may drive normally in this lane.
questions.explanation: Lane use control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. When a lane control signal contains a green arrow, drivers may drive normally in the indicated lane.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about large trucks?
questions.answerA: They take longer to stop than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerB: They all have air brakes that allow them to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: They are more maneuverable than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large trucks take longer to stop than other vehicles traveling at the same speed. The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 400 feet. However, a large truck traveling at the same speed can take almost 800 feet to stop.

questions.question: You do not have to stop for a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing if it is on a private road.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When a school bus is stopped with its red lights flashing and stop arm out, other drivers are required to stop. This law applies to drivers traveling on both public and private roads.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lines painted down the middle of the road mean:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerD: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines in the center of the road mean that passing is not allowed from either direction. You may not cross the lines unless you are making a left turn or passing pedestrians, bicyclists, and riders of scooters or skateboards when the opposite lane is clear and you can pass safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Right turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Stop before turning right.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: When may you legally drive around or under a railroad crossing gate?
questions.answerB: When you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.answerC: When the warning lights are not flashing.
questions.explanation: Do not go around or under any lowered gate at a railroad crossing. Once the gate is raised, do not proceed across the tracks until you can see clearly in both directions and are sure there are no trains coming.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Intersection ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign means that you are approaching an upcoming intersection. Watch carefully for cross traffic.

questions.question: You cannot pass safely on a two-way, two-lane street unless:
questions.answerA: You are able to clearly see the road ahead.
questions.answerB: You can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass.
questions.explanation: You cannot pass safely when driving on a two-way, two-lane street unless you can clearly see the road ahead, you can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic, and your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass. Do not pass where it is illegal and unsafe to do so.

questions.question: A solid white line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Solid lines indicate that drivers are not permitted to pass.

questions.question: Crosswalks are:
questions.answerA: Always indicated by horizontal pavement markings.
questions.answerB: Always indicated by vertical pavement markings.
questions.answerC: Always unmarked.
questions.answerD: Either indicated by pavement markings or not marked at all.
questions.explanation: Crosswalks exist whether the boundaries are marked or unmarked. You must stop behind the crosswalk to allow any pedestrians to cross.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars on the right move first.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Let cross traffic pass before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching this sign, you must yield the right-of-way. Slow down and let vehicles and pedestrians crossing your path pass before you proceed. If necessary, stop before going ahead.

questions.question: You may legally block an intersection:
questions.answerA: If you entered the intersection on the green light.
questions.answerB: During rush hour traffic.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.explanation: Even if the light is green, you may not enter an intersection unless you can get completely across before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane ends or roadway narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: Industrial area.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers that the right lane is ending or that the road is narrowing ahead.

questions.question: A vehicle suddenly cuts in front of you, creating a hazard. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Honk and step on the brake firmly.
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Swerve into the lane next to you.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle merges in front of you too closely, take your foot off of the accelerator. This will create space between you and the vehicle ahead without requiring you to slam on your brakes or swerve into another lane.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: Right lane closed.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a winding road and that they should adjust their speed accordingly.

questions.question: You want to turn left at an upcoming corner. Yield the right-of-way to:
questions.answerB: All approaching vehicles.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians on the sidewalk waiting for a "Walk" signal.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, or other vehicles moving on their green light.

questions.question: Streets and highways are most slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining hard for several hours.
questions.answerB: When they are clean and dry.
questions.answerC: Just after it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: Driving during the first half hour of rainfall is dangerous because roadways become extremely slippery when the water mixes with oil and other chemicals on the road surfaces that have not yet washed away. Use extra caution when driving on slippery roads.

questions.question: You are preparing to exit the interstate. When should you start reducing your speed?
questions.answerA: About halfway through the deceleration lane.
questions.answerB: As you approach the deceleration lane.
questions.answerC: Immediately upon entering the deceleration lane.
questions.explanation: When leaving an interstate, you should maintain your speed until you enter the deceleration lane, at which point you should reduce your speed to the exit ramp's posted advisory speed.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed and stay in your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerB: Move into the right lane and drive slowly until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the curb or edge of the road and stop until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, pull over to the right edge of the road and stop. Position yourself parallel to the curb. On one-way streets, drive toward the road edge nearest you.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. You should watch for people entering a crosswalk or crossing your path. Slow down and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: To avoid glare from the headlights of an approaching car:
questions.answerA: Look briefly toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stay focused on the centerline on the road.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams.
questions.explanation: You should avoid looking toward the bright lights of an oncoming vehicle by glancing toward the right side of the road. After looking briefly toward the side of the road, continue looking ahead to check on the position of the other vehicle.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when driving behind a large vehicle:
questions.answerA: To better see around the sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Because other drivers tend to pull behind large vehicles before trying to pass them.
questions.answerC: Because following too closely will get you caught in the vehicle's slipstream.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, and any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: Reduce your speed when:
questions.answerB: There is dense fog.
questions.answerC: It is raining.
questions.explanation: The maximum speed limit should be driven only under ideal conditions. You must reduce your speed when safety requires it, such as during snowy, icy, rainy, or foggy weather.

questions.question: You may not park within ____ of a crosswalk.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.answerC: 50 feet
questions.explanation: There are many areas where you cannot park. You may not park within 25 feet of a crosswalk or intersection.

questions.question: If you are involved in a serious motor vehicle crash:
questions.answerB: Call the police.
questions.answerC: Determine if anyone is injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, move your vehicle off of the road and stop, if possible. If anyone is injured, call 911 and provide appropriate help. You must report the crash to law enforcement if there is an injury, a death, and/or more than $1,000 in property damage (or more than $200 worth of damage made to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: In which of the following ways can alcoholic beverages affect you?
questions.answerB: It gives you a feeling of false confidence.
questions.answerC: It impairs your thinking ability.
questions.explanation: Alcohol dulls the parts of your brain that control inhibition, judgment, and self-control. As a result, you may feel stimulated, lively, and a bit giddy or foolish after consuming alcohol. Alcohol also impairs your reaction time, coordination, and balance. Your vision and ability to judge distance suffers after alcohol consumption, making it difficult to react to your surroundings.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic.
questions.answerB: Slow down without coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop completely and wait for a green light.
questions.answerD: Slow down and check for traffic.
questions.explanation: Any eight-sided sign is a stop sign. At an intersection with a stop sign, you must stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic in the intersection. Wait for the intersection to clear before proceeding.

questions.question: When may you change lanes while turning?
questions.answerA: When making a turn to the right.
questions.answerB: When making a turn to the left.
questions.answerC: When there are multiple turning lanes.
questions.explanation: When making turns, go from one lane to the other as directly as possible without crossing lane lines or interfering with traffic. Once you have completed your turn, you may change to another lane.
